content: Reduce, Reuse, Religion? A new generation of evangelicals debates swapping an antigay agenda for a pro-planet one. Jonathan Merritt doesn’t want to talk about his own views on gay marriage or civil unions -- perhaps for good reason. Merritt is a young evangelical leader, a prominent writer on modern faith, and the son of a former Southern Baptist Convention president. The religious landscape of this country may be changing, but anyone who espouses equality could derail a future leadership role among evangelicals, who still vote overwhelmingly Republican and have viewed homosexuality as a defining social issue since the early days of the Moral Majority. Merritt prefers to zoom out during an interview and opine as candid observer rather than crusader. My generation will not fight to preserve the platform for traditional marriage that our predecessors have fought for,” the 26-year-old says. “Older evangelicals are so stubborn and unable to compromise or reach out a hand. And they’re in danger of losing their legacy.” This is a very interesting article. To read in full, go to > >http://www.advocate.com/issue_story_ektid76664.asp

content: I prefer to discuss gay issues outside the religious realm for precisely the reason that's emerged here yet again, i.e. the attacks on people of faith. I think that doing so succeeds ONLY in further polarizing groups when the opposite ought to be a goal. I know evangelicals who do NOT....have an antigay agenda, so I believe that this thread title is misleading. True evangelicals believe in the salvation of immortal souls. Attacking them won't advance the GAY agenda. That said, there IS no doubt an antigay agenda has emerged in secular American society in response to....those advancing a GAY agenda (what a shock). But, it AIN'T among those who are simply followers of Jesus! This message has been edited. Last edited by: 19022583, Sat 11 April 2009 09:04 AM
